Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: A Server-Centric Approach to Data Center Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data centers have become the main networking infrastructure to
support online services, ranging from end-user applications (e.g.,
Web search and IM) to distributed system operations (e.g., GFS and
MapReduce). In this project, we explore a different design paradigm
to data center networks (DCNs). We take a new server-centric
solution approach, in contrast to the switch-centered paradigm. We
push intelligence into servers, which generally have more open and
standardized hardware architecture and software platforms. Multiple
layers of low-cost, commodity off-the-shelf, mini-switches are used
to connect servers. We leverage the large number of servers in a
data center. Even when each server just adds one more link to the
rest of servers, we obtain many links in the DCN system given the
large server population. These added links, without using high-end
switches but using only mini-switches, provide the foundation for
enhancing scalability, inter-server capacity, and fault tolerance.
Taking the approach, we can design DCNs with high scalability,
enhanced fault-tolerance, and high inter-server capacity, and better
support data center applications that exhibit various traffic
patterns of one-to-one, one-to-several, one-to-all, and all-to-all
communications. Our design also opens more space for stimulating
innovations in the DCN software through the more open programming
platform on servers, while abandoning expensive, proprietary core
switches. The results in scalable and modular data centers and
associated management tools are expected to show that, the added
complexity into servers will incur only minor systems overhead but
produce large performance gains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have obtained four research findings from this project:

1. We have explored both structured and randomized data center interconnection architectures. Our design is to leverage the large number of servers and design server-centric data centers. The resulting randomized design is represented by TrMesh, which builds on the legacy tree topology and applies small-world and power-law schemes, whereas the structured design includes BCube, DCell, etc. Our results show a small cost imposed on server computing can yield substantial benefits on communication infrastructure.

2. We have explored new information-centric data center architecture. This layer-3 design moved beyond the traditional IP and TCP protocol suite for the current Internet. Our design adapts the named data networking concept from the wired Internet to the data center context, while promoting opportunistic content sharing at the server level as a fundamental mechanism in data center networking and service. It thus offers a more complete view by showing how upper-layer models can work with the underlying layers in the content-oriented manner. This information-centric design offers new ways to provide online services, where many scientific and engineering disciplines have benefited from it.

 

3. We have proposed a suite of resource management and configuration solutions to data centers. They include novel algorithm-based auto-configuration tools to set up and verify the underlying network topology, and overload management algorithms that react to network congestion while enabling opportunistic content sharing among servers.

 

4.  We have prototyped a mobile could application to illustrate how clients benefit from the data center service by simplifying and automating conventional service. The resulting design is likely to offer other critical control-plane functions for mobile cloud services, which  hold great promise to offer better online information access to the society.

 

This project also yields fruitful results on education. It helps to renovate a new graduate course on "Selected Topics on Cloud Computing" at UCLA, which is highly popular and offered to 30-40 graduate students every year. Some research results also help to introduce the data center and cloud computing to 110+ undergraduate students via the current undergraduate course each year.  

 

The project has helped to support four PhD students, including a female candidate. The female student graduated with a PhD degree and joined academia as a tenure-track assistant professor. Another graduating PhD student plans to pursue a startup-building career path after being inspired by the research activity from this project. The third PhD student plans to stay as a postdoc fellow and pursure an academic career afterwards.
